utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: If you're going to dress like an Italian hooker, at least let it be this year's Italian hooker.

utterance.speaker: Julia
utterance.content: She's not telling us we look fat. That's a major breakthrough.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: If you didn't want to be insulted, you wouldn't have invited me.

utterance.speaker: Saleswoman
utterance.content: Would anyone like some champagne?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Yes, three glasses, please.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Mom.

utterance.speaker: Julia
utterance.content: Yeah, it's not — it's not even lunch.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: If you'd prefer, I'll make it a mimosa.

utterance.speaker: Julia
utterance.content: What do you think?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Perfect… for a night on the town. Perfect for breast-feeding.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: My heart's doing that weird thing again.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Beating? That's normal for humans.

utterance.speaker: Julia
utterance.content: Come on, Lisa, take her seriously for once.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: What? What is it?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I think we need to get you to the hospital.

utterance.speaker: TV
utterance.content: I'm dying to try it.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: Is no one gonna tell me…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Shh-shh-shh.

utterance.speaker: TV
utterance.content: How delightful.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: Why we're in the morgue?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: House is on the lam from someone. Taub's got his money on Wilson, but I'm pretty sure it's Cuddy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Fool's bet. There's a whole world of angry patients, creditors…

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She needs a doctor.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, just not me. Your mom is a 65-year-old woman with high blood pressure.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What about the macrocytic anemia?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Borderline, which is the lab equivalent of imaginary, which, by the way, matches the rest of her medical history.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You really think she's psyching herself into atrial fibrillation?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So get her a cardiologist. You don't want me involved. You don't want you involved. All that ethics stuff that I don't give a crap about suddenly makes sense. If you're emotionally invested, you cannot make rational decisions. You know this would be a disaster.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: This is my mother.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Treadmill test went well — no chest discomfort or ischemia. The abnormal rhythm will probably resolve itself, and if not, a daily pill will keep it under control. I will follow up later today.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Is it connected to my other symptoms?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Which other symptoms, Mom?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Aye… Not her fault. This "Dean of Medicine" stuff — very impressive at parties. But she's forgotten how to be a real doctor. It's all in my file.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There are 15 years of clinic visits in this file.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: I don't want to be a bother. But isn't this what you do for a living?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So… we're looking for a disease that can last a decade and a half, causes constipation, diarrhea, flu, cold, dizziness, rashes, back and joint pain, "heart feeling weird," "kishkes feeling wobbly," one actual hip replacement. And which has eluded detection by years of blood work, X-rays, and MRIs. Well, one thing does pop to mind.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: We'll monitor you, and we'll give you a thyroid test. And House's team will do a home search for environmental toxins.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: He seems to know his stuff. How come he can't afford a coat that fits?

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: No radon, no mold, no lead in the pipes.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Yeah, yeah, great. Have you seen Cuddy's high-school yearbook?

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: Okay, that is clearly not related to the case, so—

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: There is no case. Cuddy won't let House see the yearbook, so he figures there's something to hide. Any guesses? It's clearly related to being a giant teenage dork.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: So you thought I'd have some insights.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Oh, no, no. I didn't mean.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: Relax. I was crowned homecoming geek. I'm sure you can relate… because you knew some dorks.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I was the class president and head boy at — AAH!

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: Oh… Is that — is that Cuddy's mom?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Certain parts of her… and certain parts of some muscular Hispanic gentleman.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: Should we consider STDs?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I think I just caught one looking at these photos.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: What does "azarcon" mean? I—

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It means we might have an actual case.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mexican herbal medication for stomach problems, but only in the sense that lead chromate is an herb and poison is a medication.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I'll start a chelation I.V. Thank you so much. That wasn't too much of a disaster, was it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You know… that's not the only thing they found in her home.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Not my yearbook…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope. Just some stuff that could cause severe nausea and permanent erectile dysfunction… and which proves that your mom is doing the help. According to her diary, it's some contractor named Jesus… which, granted, was originally a Jewish name, but…

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Go, Mom.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: So… why were you taking a Mexican folk remedy?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: A friend uses it.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: A friend? Mom… just for medical reasons, you should have told me. If you're sexually active—

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: At my age, he's more the active one.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Mom's having a fling.

utterance.speaker: Julia
utterance.content: I know.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You do?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: She's been giving me lousy advice about it for five years. I have physical needs.

utterance.speaker: Julia
utterance.content: He's a married man, Mom.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: She doesn't want sex with him. I do want to have sex with him. Tell me, who's being hurt?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Hold on. Five years? Why didn't you tell me about it?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: I don't know. We don't have that kind of relationship. Does that really surprise you?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re not ready? You said you had two guys helping you move.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: They couldn't get out of work. I'm trying to economize. And this hotel is cheaper.

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: Hi. I'm sorry. I just wanted to drop off some mail and talk to you about something.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Of course.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Rache…

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: Chris, that's not why… We got to move on.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What does that mean? Have you moved on? With who? Is it Phil?

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: I don't want to talk about this. I know that you're worried about money, so—

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You're trying to change the subject.

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: Yeah, which you could have gleaned from, "I don't want to talk about this." I got you a tryout to be a part-time medical consultant on lawsuits.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Wait, with your brother? Have you completely forgotten the last time I saw him?

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: That was five years ago. Jamie had just found out that you'd been cheating on me with your partner's daughter. It's a little overreaction. Might have been—

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He broke my nose and then called me the most horrible person he's ever met.

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: He shouldn't have broken your nose.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You know, texts, calls, and emails all go to the same magic device these days. You only got to send one.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Then it's even weirder it took you so long to get down here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, that's a crazy mystery. It's not like I got a department to run.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: This other magic device tells me that lead poisoning wouldn't cause all my symptoms.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: True. But it could cause the 5% that are real.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: You think I'm a hypochondriac?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, let me answer this way— maybe you're imagining that I think you're a hypochondriac.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Look, my hand just started to shake. It's a side effect of these arthritis pills. Read the label.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I did… when I was typing it up, right before I slapped it on a bottle of sugar pills.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: You printed a fake label… just to prove I'm a hypochondriac?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did it work?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: It got you fired, you schmuck.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: An hour to convince her to go with Dr. Kaufman, and only then because he runs internal medicine. She wanted to leave the hospital entirely.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: My God, a woman getting better wants to leave the hospital?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: If she's getting better, it's not because you made her feel like a fool.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It couldn't be more because. If I hadn't, she'd have diagnosed herself with six new forms of cancer. She'd never leave.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It's hard enough dealing with my mom being sick. This juvenile— Yeah?

utterance.speaker: Kaufman
utterance.content: Lisa, it's gonna be okay, but she's in a-fib at 170.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Oh, God.

utterance.speaker: Kaufman
utterance.content: I think we should cardiovert while she's unsedated.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I'll be right there. A-fib's at 170.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wait. I'm sorry she's sick. I'm not sorry I'm off the case.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You're not off the case.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You don't think you can convince her—

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No, no. You are staying on. She just can't know about it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Top of the morning, Dr. Kaufman. Here's the deal. You copy me

utterance.speaker: Kaufman
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I thought you spoke to Cuddy.

utterance.speaker: Kaufman
utterance.content: Yeah. Then I spoke to the elder Cuddy, who specifically requested you not be involved.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Listen, Kauffy, you are perfectly competent, bordering on good, even. But you know I'm better. If you want, we can pretend it's 'cause I got a team and more resources. Either way, it'd be crazy to ignore my advice.

utterance.speaker: Kaufman
utterance.content: It's not gonna stop at advice. You're gonna start cutting me out, go behind me to your girlfriend. And if something goes wrong, still me standing up there alone at the M Please… stay away from my patient.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You bugged the room?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I absolutely, without apology, will admit that someone may have allegedly done so.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: Guess we can pass unethical and skip straight to illegal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not according to the recent Supreme Court case of bite versus me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This is completely unethical. Why are we listening to this?

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: I know I'm a pain, but it's impossible for me to work with you if you—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fine, fine! Instead of a live stream, I'll get a recap from Cuddy 20 minutes later — thank you for saving America.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Could be leukemia. Anemia from taking over the marrow, a-fib from infiltrating cardiac muscle.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Sounds good.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. I was really hoping for a different diagnosis — one that Kaufman hadn't already come up with. He just started a bone-marrow biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: So we don't need to do anything.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don't. You do. Go to admitting. Find us a new case. Whff! Psst, psst! Whaa! Phfffft!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: DDX.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Um, we just did it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, we just did the fake one. Why do you think I let the truth fairy know about the bug? I was testing her. She failed. She's still a narc. Thiamine deficiency fits better than leukemia.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You think she's an alcoholic?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I had dinner with Arlene. I mixed her a gin and tonic. And I'd run out of the tonic, so I substituted sleeping pills. Next morning, she assumed the blackout was from the drinking. How many old ladies are used to passing out from boozing? The answer is the boozers. We're gonna have to slip her the thiamine pills.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We've got to run this by Cuddy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why do you think I'm in such a bad mood?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Alcoholic?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Treatment's very easy, safe. It's literally a few vitamin pills. It'll fix her heart, and it won't interfere with the biopsy Kaufman's running. Put 'em in an antacid bottle. Just tell her it's for stomach problems.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I have to ask her about this.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Of course. Absolutely. You'll ask. She'll deny. You'll push it. She'll get offended. You'll be exactly where you are now, except it'll be harder to treat. You've absolutely got to do that.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I don't think she'll lie to me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She just spent the last five years going south of the border down Mexico way.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: We have our issues, but since Dad died, we tell each other the truth when asked directly. It's important to us.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Addicts lie.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Can I speak to Mom alone?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Why? You're scaring me, Lisa.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Mom, I think your drinking is causing your heart problems.

utterance.speaker: Julia
utterance.content: Is this about the champagne? She ordered—

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Patsy and Anne told me last week you lost control at the museum luncheon.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: You're talking to my friends behind my back.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: We are all concerned. Just tell me honestly… how much have you been drinking?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: I may be your patient, but I am still your mother. And I'm telling you I am not a drunk.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Okay. For your stomach pains.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: If something like that comes up again, just… do what you need to do.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And keep you out of it?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Yeah. I am being a coward, which is exactly why doctors shouldn't treat their own families. Congratulations. You were right, as usual.

utterance.speaker: Jamie
utterance.content: The hitting you was not optimal. I was going through my own divorce at the time. I have had years of therapy. Now when I get mad, I do some deep breathing, squeeze my stress ball.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Hey, I kind of deserved it.

utterance.speaker: Jamie
utterance.content: That's for sure. Here's the deal. I do a lot of med-mal, insurance. I need a new non-testifying expert. I'll give you one case as a tryout. You kick ass, I put you on retainer. Average 15 hours a week, it's 50 a year.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: 50 what?

utterance.speaker: Jamie
utterance.content: You kidding? $50,000.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I'll take it.

utterance.speaker: Jamie
utterance.content: You drive a soft bargain. You got to sign an N.D.A.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Sure. Is this…?

utterance.speaker: Jamie
utterance.content: Uh, that's a case I'm about to settle. I rep a giant pizza-delivery company. Driver hit that kid, messed up his legs.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: And gave him a microbleed in his brain, right?

utterance.speaker: Jamie
utterance.content: What? No.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: This little white mark.

utterance.speaker: Jamie
utterance.content: Your predecessor checked, so did the kid's doctors. I don't know what that is, but he's fine.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Probably. But if there's any doubt—

utterance.speaker: Jamie
utterance.content: It's a multimillion-dollar case. We're settling in two days. Lay off it, okay?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Okay. You're right. I'm off.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She spiked a fever. It's 102.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That means I was wrong about the thiamine deficiency.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You were wrong about the alcoholism.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: True dat. It's actually looking more and more like leukemia.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Kaufman rushed the biopsies. It's not cancer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So there's a bright side… Kaufman was wrong too.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: DDX.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Okay… What disease can turn Cuddy's mother into a coma patient named Stewart?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Lupus? We got fired from that case. We're moving on.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We were already fired.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: By the patient. This time by Cuddy, so it's real. She somehow realized that her completely unworkable system was completely unworkable. Okay, pop quiz, hot shots — I chose vegetable Stew for a reason. You got 60 seconds, no "hintsies."

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You're not gonna talk to us?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Exactly. You're gonna have to— Hey! You're good.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: So this is just a test?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Pupils fixed and dilated — an addict, found with an empty bottle of phenobarb next to him. How is this a mystery? It's an overdose.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: Glutethimide! Script filled last year. Could mimic fixed and dilated without the brain death… Except he'll just get better on his own, so why would you take this case?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Because House doesn't care about the treatment as long as the case is interesting.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: I'll do a blood draw and put glutethimide on the tox screen.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Really? You thought that case was interesting?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Oh, guess we're still on Arlene.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Aren't there other ways of keeping Masters occupied?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not according to my sexual harassment seminar.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Maybe it's not hypochondria. She said she gets a lot of rashes. Add the fever — sounds like autoimmune, S.L.E.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Congratulations, you can think exactly like a semi-competent internist. Kaufman's starting her on prednisone. But the heart problems were first.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Endocarditis.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: With no murmurs?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's usually a late sign.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Echo showed pristine valves.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Below the resolving threshold.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Kaufman's prednisone will suppress her immune system — could kill her.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You got to tell him it's endocarditis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Check the wiretap. His I.D. guy's been putting the same argument to him. He can't convince him. You think I got a better shot?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: So what do we do?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We switch her meds. We get a solution of broad-spectrum antibiotics, stick it in an I.V. bag marked for prednisone. Kaufman can only be there a few times a day. Tell Arlene you're from the pharmacy, switch 'em out.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: This is nuts. This is way too complicated.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's hanging an I.V. bag!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If the attending doesn't know what she's on, the risk of drug reaction—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What risk? We know how he's treating her. We bugged the room.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: This is not about information! We're talking ethical and legal violations on a scale that should make even you puke!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She's dying!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That doesn't mean we should all go to jail to save her! You're losing control because… this is your girlfriend's mom.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You gonna run this by Cuddy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. She said to keep her out of it, do what we need to do. Look, I know what I'm suggesting is completely screwed up. That's because this situation is completely screwed up. Do it, or you're fired.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We stick together, he can't fire all three of us.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Give me your prescription pad.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Why are you doing this?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Because I think it's endocarditis, and I think the prednisone will kill her. And I forgot my prescription pad.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Am I a horrible person? I used to win awards for volunteer work. I went to Guatemala and fixed cleft palates. Now we're sitting back letting Chase do our dirty work.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We're doing the right thing — stay out of it.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I don't know. I don't know about anything anymore. Then this thing with the kid, Rachel's brother—

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Stay out of that too.

utterance.speaker: A
utterance.content: radiologists — experts, unlike you — said no bleed.

utterance.speaker: B
utterance.content: you yourself said it's probably not.

utterance.speaker: C
utterance.content: you've got no doctor-patient relationship.

utterance.speaker: D
utterance.content: you'll lose your consulting job.

utterance.speaker: E
utterance.content: your ex will kill you.

utterance.speaker: F
utterance.content: I'm running out of alphabet here.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You do it?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Had the bag, walking towards the room, and Cuddy's sister says, "Hey, Dr. Chase." I met her at that charity event last year. One of you two has got to do this.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I met Arlene at the same benefit.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Conveniently. Come on, don't ask me. I don't even know if I believe it's endo— Damn it. It's Rachel's brother. He wants me to check out some new case.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Conveniently.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It's a tryout. I need this job. I got to do this.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So you're just gonna ditch us, run off, and work on some other case?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Are you Timothy's mom?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: My name is Christopher Taub. I'm a doctor at Princeton Plainsboro. I saw your son's file. I think he might have a very small bleed in his brain.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Your son could die of a brain hemorrhage. He needs a cerebral angiogram today. Get in your car and meet me at the hospital.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Another pop quiz. How many idiot doctors does it take to switch an I.V.? The longer we wait, the more the prednisone is gonna kill her immune system. Forget playing pharmacist. Mom naps every afternoon. Wait by the room. When she falls asleep, get the sister out somehow.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: Hi, Dr. Cuddy, is now a good time to talk?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Not really.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: So, um, you know how you had us consulting and then stopped having us consult?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Why are you still here?

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: Um, well, I think the stopping might have… stopped. House put me on this weird case where there's no treatment — I think maybe to distract me. Uh, and they've been acting odd.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I'll look into it. Thank you for coming to me.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: Because I-I'm worried that he's switching your mother's medications. I checked with the pharmacy — Dr. Chase got prednisone and antibiotics for my coma patient, which wouldn't treat him, but could treat conditions that cause… heart failure.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You told me to keep you out of it, do what I needed to do. What the hell did you think that meant?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I meant, like, if you had to slip her a few more vitamin pills or something. This is life-threatening! It's illegal. I wasn't expecting something like this.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Only because you intentionally weren't thinking about it 'cause you don't want to make any tough decisions.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Are you completely sure it's endocarditis?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's not a real question. Endocarditis fits better than the alternatives. We're having a little trouble hanging the right I.V. The fastest way is with you help.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Where'd Julia go?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: She's got a family.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I've got a family.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Three kids and a husband — that's a family.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You are always tougher on me than Julia. Why is that?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: I'm not.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I was thinking about when you made me run for yearbook editor — I didn't want to. I didn't have a social life my whole senior year. You let Julia do whatever she wanted.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: We're debating 12th grade now?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Like anything's changed.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: What do you want, Lisa? Do you want to hear I love you both the same? Of course I do.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: But times like this, when we argue, it reminds me… I have more in common with her. She's nicer to me. I love you both… but I like her more than you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I called you three times.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: My phone wasn't exactly on. I figure I'll be getting some angry calls once radiology sends back the angiogram.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: They already did. Here… this is what you saw. It's an anatomical variant of the skull — the bone in proximity to a blood vessel. There was nothing wrong with him. That was reason "G."

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: That's good news for him.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Lungs clear?

utterance.speaker: Kaufman
utterance.content: Diffuse wheezing, tightness, pruritis.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It's an allergic reaction.

utterance.speaker: Kaufman
utterance.content: Looks like. Doesn't make any sense. She's on prednisone. How could she get an allergic reaction?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I switched out the antibiotics, put her back on prednisone — her breathing's normal. But the a-fib's back, and her fever's up.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Allergy's got to be due to our antibiotics.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does Kaufman know what we did? That's good.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No, that is terrible! He doesn't know that she got worse on antibiotics, so now he's thinking endocarditis. He'll put her back on the antibiotics that almost suffocated her. What do we do?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We push through this. It started in the heart. Endocarditis still fits. It's just got to be fungal. We have to switch Kaufman's antibiotics for amphotericin B.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I don't know if you're right. I don't care. But we are gonna end up killing this woman if we keep confusing her attending with these secret meds.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don't care about confusing the attending! I want this woman—

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We're not talking about simple antibiotics anymore. Amphotericin B is dangerous in itself. It's a poison. That's why it kills fungi. It'll give her fever, chills—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which she already has, which will help us hide it.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I don't think I can take a risk like that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, then you shouldn't have let her fire me! Look, all you have to do is switch the I.V.s again.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: This has blown up on you once already.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He's right.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yep.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I'm so sorry I got you guys into this. You should go.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm right.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I know. And I'll do it, but—

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: I agree. Fungal endocarditis fits. But we still have to tell your mother. I don't want to tell her, not at all. But the patient is the highest priority.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm kicking you out of your office. Yes, you. This is not her office yet. If you tell anyone, I will get you thrown out of med school, and I will destroy your career.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: I've thought about that. Lying about me… won't work. Everybody knows your reputation.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: True… but I won't have to lie. Buried in your coma patient's big, big file is a form that doesn't allow treatment without the expressed consent of the relatives.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: Wait…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You drew blood. And that's not just a screw-up. It's a criminal assault.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: But you told me—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. As you may recall…

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: You set me up? Why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because this patient is the highest priority.

utterance.speaker: Jamie
utterance.content: You made her think I was hiding her son being sick! She scuttled the settlement. She reported me to the bar. I got to deal with that crap now. I will sue you for slander, for tortious interference, and anything else I can use to destroy you. Oh, and my sister says stay out of her life… You failure. Five years of therapy.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: Dr. Kaufman? I need to speak with you and the patient alone.

utterance.speaker: Kaufman
utterance.content: I'm skipping the credentials committee. I'm going straight to the state board and reporting you for — what you've done is so off the spectrum, I don't know there's a specific name for it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I think he's talking to you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Marty, calm down.

utterance.speaker: Kaufman
utterance.content: And you — what you did is worse. He's an insane lunatic. You're the Dean of Medicine!

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: I want you off my case.

utterance.speaker: Kaufman
utterance.content: That's exactly right.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Don't get excited. You're fired too.

utterance.speaker: Kaufman
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: I'll never get away from House or my daughter if I stay here. Transfer me

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Mom… you're very ill, and you're very angry. You really think now is the right time to make a decision like this?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: You lied to me and betrayed me. Do you think I really care what you consider a good idea anymore?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I'll get the ambulance.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Happy?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I can't believe it. What just happened?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You just killed her.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Are you blaming me? This is all because you're so arrogant, you goaded her into firing you!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Actually, my mistakes started a little after that, when I agreed to your brilliant scheme to keep me on the case after she'd fired me off it.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She would have left the hospital.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Only 'cause you would have let her, like you did just now.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You think I can control her?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don't know. I've never seen you try.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I have been rebelling against this woman my entire life.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Here's what I've seen. She insults you, you complain to me. I drug her at dinner, you never let her know. We slip her medicine, happens behind her back. You never confront her… and it pisses me off.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Are you taking this personally?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She leaves, she dies. One day… maybe a week from now, maybe a year from now, you're gonna decide that the man sleeping next to you killed your mother. Get me my patient back.

utterance.speaker: Julia
utterance.content: This is really bad, Lise.

utterance.speaker: Lisa
utterance.content: I swear to God, Jules, I will call security! I asked you before why you were tough on me.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: I wasn't.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You were. And I know why. You see something in me that you didn't see in Julia and you didn't see in you — a type of ambition, a type of brains. That's why you rode me. You made me yearbook editor, summa undergrad, A.O.A. in med school. The only time I ever see light in your eyes is when you hear me talking about my job. The reason you keep coming to see me in the clinic is because you trust me. You trust my medical judgment. So here it is. If you transfer to Princeton General, you'll be treated well, and you'll die. If you stay here with House, you'll be treated badly, but you'll live. I don't care if I have to slash the tires of every ambulance in this bay, Mom. I am not letting you leave my hospital.

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: One, two, three.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I got it. How you feeling, Mom?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: I feel a little dizzy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your heart's still weak from the infection. We'll hang an antifungal I.V.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: If you're so great, how come you're not running your department anymore?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What are you talking about, Mom?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: That's what he told me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Two days ago? I said that I didn't have a department to run, I was being sarcastic.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: No, you weren't.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right, because people who are talking can't tell if they're being sarcastic.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: That doesn't make any sense. Of course they can. But you weren't.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I love A-Rod. He's soooo modest. And I highly respect the paintings he has of himself as a centaur. Question — do I like A-Rod?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: Yes… Whoever he is.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She can't recognize sarcasm?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Deficit in the right parahippocampal gyrus, which means CNS involvement before the fever. I was wrong about the endocarditis.

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: I-I don't — I don't feel—

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Mom? Mom! Heart rate 170. Nurse! Do something.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I am.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: House!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The fever was hypothalamic. That means brain, heart, anemia, allergy. You hear that, what do you think?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I don't know.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You think heavy-metal toxicity.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It can't be. You treated with chelation for lead.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She got better, then she got worse. She never stopped being poisoned.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You really want me to stop and explain? There it is. Look at that.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The muscle's black. Necrosis?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Metallosis. Her artificial hip "weared and teared" way too much. It's cobalt poisoning. We need Chase to get an O.R. I'm gonna start chelation again.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I thought you didn't want to see me.

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: I didn't. Foreman called me. I didn't know that you thought that little boy had a bleed in his head. I will kill my brother if he messes with you anymore.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What do you care?

utterance.speaker: Rachel
utterance.content: Chris… you were a crappy husband… but you are a good person.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Once again, you are unfired.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You sold me out even though you knew that you were gonna get thrown out of med school. That's just… kind of impressive.

utterance.speaker: Masters
utterance.content: I keep my job if I stand up to you. I keep it if I don't. I… don't buy it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When Cuddy was protecting me before, she was protecting a doctor. She's now protecting a boyfriend. The hospital's not gonna put up with that for long. So I need you to protect me from doing something Cuddy will regret. See you bright and late tomorrow.

utterance.speaker: Julia
utterance.content: Mom… Why would you want to keep this?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: So I can mount it on the wall, like a moose head. It says here cobalt can cause rashes, dizziness, and stomach problems. You still think I've been imagining the whole thing?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Okay, you might have a point. How do you feel?

utterance.speaker: Arlene
utterance.content: You know, a little dizziness… some pain.
